subject: Productivity
title: Atomic Clocks and Nanosecond Precision
description: A micro-lesson that makes Atomic Clocks and Nanosecond Precision usable.

hook.text: Your GPS works because satellites carry clocks accurate to one billionth of a second.

buildup.text: Atomic clocks measure vibrations of cesium atoms. They lose less than one second every 300 million years.

discovery.text: The first atomic clock was built in 1955 at the UK's National Physical Laboratory.

twist.text: GPS signals travel at light speed. A tiny clock error of a microsecond means a 300-meter location mistake.

climax.text: Modern civilization depends on time precision no human can perceive but every system requires.

quiz.question: When was the first atomic clock built?
